head.title: The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors

article.h1: The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors

span.span: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, 60208-3112, USA
Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Institut für Physik, Invalidenstraße 110, D-10115 Berlin, Germany

div.p: We present a model calculation for the temperature dependent behaviour of surface states on a ferromagnetic local-moment film. The film is described within the s-f model featuring local magnetic moments being exchange coupled to the itinerant conduction electrons. The surface states are generated by modifying the hopping in the vicinity of the surface of the film. In the calculation for the temperature dependent behaviour of the surface states we are able to reproduce both Stoner-like and spin-mixing behaviour in agreement with recent (inverse) photoemission data on the temperature dependent behaviour of a Gd(0001) surface state.

In the recent past many theoretical and experimental research works have been focussed on the intriguing properties of rare earth metals and their compounds. On the exeperimental side, this interest was aroused after Weller et al. reported on the existence of the magnetically ordered Gd(0001) surface at temperatures where the bulk Gadolinium is paramagnetic [2]. Since then, a variety of different experimental techniques has been applied to the problem by different groups yielding values of the surface Curie temperature enhancement, Δ⁢TC=TC⁢(surface)-TC⁢(bulk)Δsubscript𝑇𝐶subscript𝑇𝐶surfacesubscript𝑇𝐶bulkDelta italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( surface CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bulk CLOSE:)\Delta T_{C}=T_{C}({\rm surface})-T_{C}({\rm bulk}), between 17K and 60K [3, 4, 5]. Contrary to the groups cited above Donath et al. using spin-resolved photoemission did not find any indication for an enhanced Curie temperature at the Gd(0001) surface [6], fueling the controversial discussion.

Concerning the interplay between electronic structure and exceptional magnetic properties at the Gadolinium surface a Gd(0001) surface state [7, 8] is believed to play a crucial role and its temperature dependent behaviour has been discussed intensely [6, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]. Recently, the investigation of the correlation between strain induced alteration of the surface electronic structure and enhanced magnetization in Gd films has been addressed by a number of experimental works [14, 15, 16, 17]. A thorough account on the surface magnetism and the surface electronic structure of the lanthanides has been given by Dowben et al. [18].

Rare-earth materials are so-called local-moment systems, i.e. the magnetic moment stems from the partially filled 4f-shell of the rare-earth atom being strictly localized at the ion site. Thus the magnetic properties of these materials are determined by the localized magnetic moments. On the other hand, the electronic properties like electrical conductivity are borne by itinerant electrons in rather broad conduction bands, e.g. 6s, 5d for Gd. Many of the characteristics of local-moment systems can be attributed to a correlation between the localized moments and the itinerant conduction electrons. For this situation the s-f model has been proven to be an adequate description. In this model, the correlation between localized moments and conduction electrons is represented by an intraatomic exchange interaction.

In a previous paper we have presented an approximate treatment of the special case of a single electron in an otherwise empty conduction band [20]. This exactly soluble limiting case gives the approximate solution for finite temperatures a certain trustworthiness.

div.p: Taking into account Eqs. (12)-(The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors), we have now a closed system of equations, provided that the f-spin correlation functions appearing in Eqs. (The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors) are known.

These can be evaluted by considering the magnetic subsystem, according to the Hamiltonian ℋfsubscriptℋ𝑓caligraphic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal H}_{f} (Eq. (3)). For all what concerns us in this paper it is only interesting that, employing an RPA-type decoupling, a solution of the magnetic subsystem can be found[19] and that it gives us all the necessary layer-dependent f-spin correlation functions as a function of temperature from T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 to the Curie temperature, T=TC𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} [20]. Mediated by Eqs. (14)-(The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors), the f-spin correlation functions contain the whole temperature dependence of the electronic subsystem.

To briefly recall the main results presented in our previous paper [20], Fig. 1 shows the density of states of a s.c.-(100) double layer for different s-f interactions and different temperatures. In the case of ferromagnetic saturation, T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0, we see that for the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron the density of states of the free case J=0𝐽0italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0J=0 (dotted line) is just rigidly shifted when the interaction is switched on. This is due to the impossibility of the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron to exchange its spin with the perfectly alligned local-moment system. For the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron in the case of small s-f exchange coupling, J>0𝐽0italic-J RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0J>0, a slight deformation of the free density of states sets in. For intermediate and strong couplings (J⪆0.2greater-than-or-approximately-equals𝐽0.2italic-J RELOP:greater-than-or-approximately-equals NUMBER:0.2J\gtrapprox 0.2), the density of states splits into two parts, corresponding to two different spin exchange processes between the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron and the localized f-spin system. The higher energetic part represents a polarization of the immediate spin neighbourhood of the electron due to the repeated emission and reabsorption of magnons. The corresponding polaron-like quasiparticle is called the magnetic polaron. The low-energetic part of the spectrum is a scattering band which can be explained by the simple emission of a magnon by the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron without reabsorption, but necessarily connected with a spin flip of the electron [24].

For T>0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0T>0 we see in Fig. 1 that with increasing temperature for the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron spectral weight is transferred from the high-energetic polaron peak to the low-energetic scattering peak. On the other hand, for the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron we have the effect that for finite temperatures an additional peak rises at the high energetic side of the spectrum. This rise with increasing temperature is fueled by the loss of spectral weight on the low-energetic peak. The high-energetic peak simply represents the ability of the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron to exchange its spin with a not perfectly aligned local-moment system, T>0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0T>0 [20]. As a result of the shifts of spectral weight occuring for both, the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow and spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow spectra, the spectra for the two spin directions approach each other with increasing temperature. In the limiting case of T→TC→𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T ARROW:rightarrow italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\rightarrow T_{C} the system has eventually lost its ability to distinguish between the two possible spin directions because of the loss of magnetization of the underlying local-moment system. Hence, for T=TC𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} the densities of states of the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron are equal. Another feature which can be seen in Fig. 1 is that while the positions of the quasiparticle subbands stays pretty much the same we observe a narrowing of the bands with increasing temperature. This can especially well be seen for the case of temperature evolvement of spectrum of the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron for the case of J=0.2𝐽0.2italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2J=0.2. Whereas the scattering band and the polaron band are, for the case of T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0, still merged, in the case of T=TC𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} both bands are clearly separated.

In this paper we are interested in surface states and their temperature dependent behaviour. Surface states occur in the spectral density at energies different from the bulk energies and are localized in the vicinity of the surface of a crystal. The theory presented above is applied to a s.c. film consisting of n𝑛italic-nn layers oriented parallel to the (100)-surface as drawn schematically in Fig. 2.

In reality the variation of the hopping integrals in the vicinity of the surface may be caused e.g. by a relaxation of the interlayer distance. According to the scaling law T∼r-5similar-to𝑇superscript𝑟5italic-T RELOP:similar-to italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim r^{-5} for the d-electrons [25] a relatively small top-layer relaxation Δ⁢r/rΔ𝑟𝑟Delta italic-r MULOP:divide italic-r\Delta r/r may result in a strong change of the hopping integral T𝑇italic-TT. Thus e.g. a relaxation of the Gd(0001) surface layer of 3-6% (cf. [26] and references therein) would yield a modification of the hopping integrals of of up to 30%.

In a previous paper we have been dealing with surface states for the exactly solvable case of a single electron in an otherwise empty conduction band and a ferromagnetically saturated f-spin system, T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 [27]. For this special case we have shown that modifying the hopping in the vicinity of the surface according to Eqs. (18) leads to the appearance of surface states in the local spectral density S𝐤⁢σα⁢αsubscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝛼𝐤𝜎italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS^{\alpha\alpha}_{{\bf k}\sigma}. Modifying the hopping within the surface layer by more than 25%, i.e. ϵ∥⪅34subscriptitalic-ϵparallel-to34italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\epsilon_{\parallel}\lessapprox\frac{3}{4} or ϵ∥⪆54greater-than-or-approximately-equalssubscriptitalic-ϵparallel-to54italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:5 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\epsilon_{\parallel}\gtrapprox\frac{5}{4}, while keeping all the other hopping integrals unchanged results in a single surface state at the lower or the upper edge of the bulk band [27, 28]. This surface state first emerges at the Γ¯¯ΓOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start Gamma ARG:end\bar{\Gamma}- and at the M¯¯MOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start M ARG:end\bar{\rm M}-point from the bulk band and from there spreads for larger modifications of ϵ∥subscriptitalic-ϵparallel-toitalic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{\parallel} to the rest of the Brillouin zone.

On the other hand, when the hopping within the first layer remains constant, ϵ∥≡1subscriptitalic-ϵparallel-to1italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:1\epsilon_{\parallel}\equiv 1, but the hopping between the first and the second layer is significantly increased, ϵ⟂⪆2greater-than-or-approximately-equalssubscriptitalic-ϵperpendicular-to2italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-approximately-equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end\epsilon_{\perp}\gtrapprox\sqrt{2}, then two surface states split off one on each side of the bulk band. Both types of surface states for the special case of T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 can be observed at the single bulk band and on the high-energetic polaron band for the case of the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron and the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron, respectively.

Here, we are interested in the possible variations of the T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 surface states when going to finite temperatures. Figs. 3 to 5 show the temperature dependence of surface states for the different possible variations of the hopping in the vicinity of the surface. All the calculations for Figs. 3 to 5 have been performed for a 20-layer s.c. film cut parallel to the (100)-plane of the s.c. crystal. For much thinner films than 20 layers the calculation of surface states becomes meaningless since there is no real bulk-like environment in the center of the film to compare the electronic states at the surface to. So it is desirable to calculate thicker films for the discussion of surface states. The choosen thickness of our model film is basically a compromise between computational accuracy and computational time. The parameters for the uniform hopping according to Eqs. (18) and for the s-f exchange interaction are T=-0.1𝑇0.1italic-T RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.1T=-0.1 and J=0.1𝐽0.1italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1J=0.1, respectively.

Eq. (18b)). Such a drastic modification of the hopping integrals in the vicinity of the surface is rather unlikely to occur in reality. This surface state can most clearly be seen at the Γ¯¯ΓOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start Gamma ARG:end\bar{\Gamma}-point and the M¯¯MOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start M ARG:end\bar{\rm M}-point in the two-dimensional Brillouin zone. This results in equal populations of the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow peaks at T=TC𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C}.

To round up the picture we see in Fig. 5 the case where the hopping between the first and the second layer is modified, ϵ⟂=2subscriptitalic-ϵperpendicular-to2italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2\epsilon_{\perp}=2, while the hopping within the first layer remains equal to the uniform hopping within the film, ϵ∥≡1subscriptitalic-ϵparallel-to1italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:parallel-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:1\epsilon_{\parallel}\equiv 1. Here we have for T=0𝑇0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 two surface states, one on each side of the bulk spectrum. When the temperature is switched on the surface states on the outer side of the bulk dispersion behave Stoner-like, while the surface states on the inner side of the bulk dispersion exhibit a spin-mixing behaviour.

Apparently, our model is able to reproduce a Stoner like collapse of the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow peak positions for TCsubscript𝑇𝐶italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{C} as well as a spin-mixing behaviour. In the spin-mixing case there are two peaks which both have a majority- and a minority-spin contribution. When the temperature is increased, the spectral weight of these contributions is altered until for T=TC𝑇subscript𝑇𝐶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} for each peak the spin-↓↓ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-↑↑ARROW:uparrow\uparrow contributions have the same spectral weights.

In being able to reproduce both Stoner-like and spin-mixing behaviour, depending on the variation of the hopping and the position in the Brillouin zone, our model calculations are in harmony with more recent (inverse) photoemission studies on Gd(0001) films which abandoned the grasp of earlier works that the temperature dependent behaviour of the Gd(0001) surface state has to be either Stoner-like or of spin-mixing type [12, 13]. Especially, it has been shown here that for certain parameters it is possible to observe both kinds of behaviour at the same time (see Fig. 5). This feature of our model calculation seems to be in strong agreement with a scenario proposed by Donath and Gubanka [12].
